title: Walton Hall Park Walking Route

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Walton Hall Lake and Sundial
images.caption: Walton Hall Lake and sundial, Wakefield, West Yorkshire. Walton Hall was the home of the 19th-century eccentric naturalist Charles Waterton. The Hall, now a hotel and restaurant, is on an island reached by an elegant footbridge. This view shows Waterton's elaborate sundial.

images.title: Pauline Eccles, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Walton Hall, dwarfed by a giant beech tree. Golfers wander across the course with the magnificent Palladian style mansion.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Walton Hall and lake, Walton
images.caption: Walton Hall and lake, Walton

images.title: Steve Partridge / Weathered Sandstone at Waterton Park.
images.caption: Weathered Sandstone at Waterton Park. While walking the dogs one day, the pattern on this piece of sandstone caught my eye. It almost looks like woodgrain. This is a section of the Waterton Park perimeter wall, also known as Walton Hall. Walton Hall is famous not only locally but throughout the world as the home of Charles Waterton, the famous naturalist who died in 1865. Squire Waterton transformed the lake and its surrounding parkland into the world's first wildfowl reserve and sanctuary. Many species still breed here today. Walton Hall was built by Charles Waterton's father in the eighteenth century.

description: A walk around the pretty parkland surrounding Walton Hall in Wakefield. Walton Hall is a Georgian mansion on an island surrounded by its own lake. The walk takes you past the lake, into the peaceful woodland of Haw Park Wood and then along the Barnsley Canal. The Trans Pennine Trail runs past the park so you could continue your walk along the Barnsley Canal or head to the nearby Anglers Country Park .
display_address: Otter Close, Walton, Wakefield, West Yorkshire, England, WF2 6UF, United Kingdom
